ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe? and we talked about different ways to stay safe. Do you remember the different ways the dinosaurs learned to stay safe?
In this activity, we will look at pictures of people doing things to stay safe. We’ll ask and answer questions about how they are being safe.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card. Offer extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity by using the next picture card.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: We’ve learned a lot about safety and different ways to stay safe during our different activities. Now we can talk more about why staying safe is important.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Use the Ask and Support sections of the picture card for younger and developmentally delayed children. Encourage conversation by asking children to describe what they see on the card.
Encourage children to talk about the different ways people can help each other stay safe. Have children name ways that they can work together to stay safe in the classroom and on the playground.

Encourage children to act out a way to be safe that is shown on the picture cards. For example, children can pretend to put on a helmet or a seatbelt when those cards are shown. This will help children develop stronger language skills.

Invite children to respond to the picture cards by drawing pictures. They may want to represent a way to stay safe. Support children as they talk about what they are drawing and encourage them to use describing words.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe? and we talked about empathy, which means understanding how other people feel. We talked about different things we can do to help other people feel better. We also talked about how important it is to follow rules and routines in the classroom.
In this activity, we will look at pictures of children and talk about how we think they are feeling. We will sort them into two groups:

ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-speaking: Happy is for the children who are smiling or laughing.
Not Happy is for children who are not smiling or laughing.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Hand Signals Ask children to give a thumbs up if the children on the card look happy and a thumbs down if the children look sad. Model.
Ask Show one picture card to the group and ask the question on the back of the card. Offer support or challenge as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Show the next picture card and repeat steps above.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: All the photos on this side show children who look h (happy). How do you know they are happy?
All the photos on this side show children who do not look happy. How do you know they are not happy?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Invite children to tell what is happening in the photo and to describe the look the person has on their face. Encourage children to talk about what the person in the picture is doing.

Encourage children to engage in peer-to-peer conversation about the pictures and how to show that they understand how someone is feeling. Remind children of the rule that they should listen while someone is talking.

Children whose first language is Spanish may recognize the Spanish cognate empatía for the English word empathy. If not, write the two words side by side so children can see them. Help children make this connection. Understanding the connection between the two words should help English learners better understand the word empathy.

Invite children to respond to the picture cards by drawing and writing faces of people feeling sad or happy. As they draw, encourage children to think about how they treat people who are feeling these ways.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe?, written by Jane Yolen and illustrated by Mark Teague. We learned about different ways to stay safe. We talked about activities we do outside.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-talk-emphasis: Review the Vocabulary Use the Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words helmet and climb.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will look at pictures of people being safe in different ways. We will discuss each picture and then we will tell whether the person is being safe inside or outside.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card to the group and ask the question on the back of the picture card, offering support or challenge as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Show the next card and repeat steps above.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: All of the cards on this side show people being safe ou (outside). How can you tell that they are outside?
All of the cards on this side show people being safe i (inside). How can you tell that they are inside? Is what they are doing different from the outside activities?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: For younger and developmentally delayed children, read aloud the Ask and Support section of each card. Then, ask children to tell what else they know about what the card shows. Encourage conversation

Encourage children to name other activities that they do outside (for example, climbing on monkey bars). Have children talk about ways they can stay safe during those activities, such as by staying near adults or by wearing sunscreen.

Encourage children to use a physical response to the cards. If they see a child riding a bike and wearing a helmet, they can pretend to put on a helmet. If they see a child skating, they can move their legs, pretending to skate. These responses will help children participate in the activity as their language skills develop.
Encourage children to play this game outdoors, where they can act out the outside activities. Remind them of what the children on the cards do to stay safe.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read Five Little Froggies Jumping on the Bed, and we learned more about staying safe.
We learned the words little and jumping. Let’s talk about those words since we will use them when we do our activity.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-talk-emphasis: Use the little and jumping Vocabulary Cards to revisit the words.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will look at pictures and say if the child in the picture is being safe or not being safe.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card and ask the questions on the back of the card. Offer support or challenge as needed.
Sort Make signs to indicate a column for “safe” and a column for “not safe.” Give the picture card to a child to line up in one of the columns.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.
Talk About Being Safe All of the pictures on this side show children being safe. What are they doing to stay safe?
Talk About Not Being Safe All of the pictures on this side show children who are doing something that is not safe. What are they doing that is not safe?

For younger or developmentally delayed children, read aloud the Ask and Support sections of each card. Then, ask children what else they know about what the children are doing and whether it is safe. Encourage conversation by asking children to describe what they see.
Challenge children to come up with different ways that the children in the pictures can be safe.

Encourage children to respond verbally by asking an adult for help for one of the unsafe cards. For example, when they see something unsafe in a picture, such as a child unsafely climbing on a chair, they can ask an adult for help in their home language.

Invite children to draw a response to the pictures using pens, crayons, or markers. Encourage them to talk as they draw, using the past tense to describe situations they experienced similar to those shown on the cards.
